comment._content: Thomas Green and Sons built steam engines from 1835 and the following is taken from a flickr colleagues gallery of their history. 1880s Started building locomotives. •1885-98 157 tram locomotives built. www.flickr.com/photos/johnnyg1955/galleries/7215762364661...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Why would a Dublin and Belfast locomotive be hauling a tram around Terenure? It's a bit off their turf, isn't it?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The engine plaque seems to say someone (Rodgers?) and Son makers 1906/8.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Not Dublin & Belfast. The Dublin and Blessington Steam Tramway is a more likely candidate. The first locomotives were six brand new tramway type 0-4-0 tank locomotives purchased from the Falcon Works, Loughborough in 1887. They were numbered from 1 to 6, and just one of these, number 6, lasted until the close of the tramway in 1932, having been completely rebuilt at the Midland Great Western Railway works at Broadstone in 1914. These locomotives were known informally as the 'kettles'. They were never a great success, as they were rather underpowered for the job in hand..... ....In 1896 came number 8, an 0-4-2 tank also built by Thos. Green & Son, and smaller than number 7. It was rebuilt as a 2-4-2T in 1903, to become similar to number 9. Number 9 arrived in 1899, a 2-4-2T built by the Brush Engineering Works, Loughborough. The last new locomotive to arrive was built by Thos. Green & Son in 1906, also similar to number 9, and received number 2 in replacement for the original number 2 which was withdrawn and scrapped. It was renumbered as number 10 in 1915, and both numbers 9 and 10 were the only other locomotives to last to the end in 1932. This being the new engine number 2, it dates the photo between 1906 and 1915.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: That site with the history of the tramways lists "passing loops" at Templeogue, Tallaght, Jobstown, The Embankment, Crooksling, The Brittas Inn, The Lamb, and Blessington itself. Several more passing loops out on the Poulaphouca extension. After the Embankment stop, the trams climbed steeply for one and a half miles to Crooksling, some 700 feet above sea level. At one point the gradient reached 1 in 20, and the trams rarely bettered 5mph up the steep incline. There were many incidences of trams running out of control down this hill, and in one case, a locomotive ran away, derailing at the bottom of the hill.

comment._content: Thomas Green seems to be the likely builder, Wikipedia has other builders with " Son/Sons" in the name, no others seem to have that name with a "reen". en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Locomotive_manufacturers_o... They apparently built one of the first lawnmowers! :)

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content:
The loco appears to have two cabs, for operation where there was no turntable to "turn the engine around". We call them push/pull here, a configuration still used for commuter trains.

You get out of one end and walk to the other cab, and either push or pull the cars.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Odd that the locomotive is running without lights. It should have one top centre to signify an ordinary passenger train. You also wouldn't be able to stoke from the far end, which suggests that it's oil fired.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Carol comments on the fact that there are first and third class seats. The difference is that the third class are open, while the first class are not. Following a steam engine in an open car can be an uncomfortable experience:

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: From 1875 to 1956 the next best thing to a first-class train ticket was a third-class train ticket. There was no second-class on British trains during that period. William Gladstone insisted that a third-class should be created for poorer people. The train companies hated this and thus ran useless third-class services known as Parliamentary trains just to apply to the law. Then they had a better idea which was to upgrade third-class to second-class, but still call it third-class. Train companies had other interesting ideas, such as using chimney sweeps to cover the inside of the carriages with soot to make people wanting to travel in third-class upgrade to first-class to avoid getting dirty.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Newspaper report of the inquest. into the death of a man knocked down by the D & B steam tram near Terenure College in 1900. Judging from this and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03]'s photo, the jury drawing the attention of the authorities to "the unprotected state of the tramlines" had little effect. Testimony also reveals that the Board of Trade regulations limited speed to 12 mph.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

All I can say is that nearly 12 months of squinting at things has ruined my eyes. Will make sure to have spanking new pince-nez for the New Year. And have now tagged this photo with Terenuricity in honour of [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]'s locationing (technical term) skills... Is this one safe to leave at 1910-ish, or did I miss anything in the comments?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: You may wonder, as this is the terminus, where the track that continues past the terminus is going. Goods wagons and cattle cars from Blessington direction would be parked there, and then collected at night by an electric locomotive, and taken over the electric tramlines into the city.

The tram car had a roof because of sparks from the coal-fired steam tram loco.
The roof was done away with when double-deck electric trams were introduced.

comment.author: 56911765@N04
comment._content:
Anyone local knows this lines association with a pub called the Morgue in Templeogue (now a Dublin suburb) here's why:

The Morgue was first licenced in 1848, it was licenced under the Ruling British government as a public house, part of the duties of the pub under the licence, was to provide certain public services one of these services was to provide the services that would normally fall on an undertakers.
At the time Templeogue was in the country side and was the last proper town before Blessington, so it was common place, that if anyone died in the surrounding area, the bodies of the dead would be left in the pub until the coroner, constable or priest was available to examine the body.
In the year 1888 the Dublin Blessington Steam Tram opened for Business, the Tram-line changed the Templeogue Inn forever, The pub had also a new duty, it became a ticket office for the Tram and also earned it’s famous nickname.
Many people were killed by the tram (owing to not only it’s speed, but also the lack of noise), including many who were worse for drink, the tram line ran less than two feet from the front door of the pub, on several occasions people would leave the pub, get knocked down right outside the front door and there bodies would be brought straight back into the pub.
